results.title: Coming of age in Oxley
results.brief_description: Don Heath and his wife, both teachers, moved to Oxley (10 km south-east of Wangaratta) in 1975, fell in love with the small rural town and decided to settle there. In this short interview Don talks of Oxley, and his coming of age in 1986 when he and his wife finally bought 4 acres of land and built their own home - a home that he loves and a place where there is plenty of space and freedom for his three young children.

results.title: The Heroes
results.brief_description: A boy with a creative impulse is exposed to the influence of war toys through his companion and through commercialism. His conscience forces him to resist. He cannot decide what is better, reation or destruction. He eventually finds destruction more amusing than appreciation or creation, he abandons his drawing pad and runs off to play war. Music composed and sung by Glen Tomasetti.

results.title: The Hermitage: art treasures tour (PC)
results.brief_description: This interactive CD-ROM takes the viewer on a tour of the State Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg, Russia. The museum was built during the 18th century to house the private art collection of the Tsars, today it houses more than 3,000,000 artefacts from Prehistory to Modern Day. You can take your pick of video clips about Rembrandt, French, Roman and Italian Art; look at music and the arts, in particular Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky; take guided tours of Russian, Western European and Oriental Art, the Golden Chamber, architecture, art of classical antiquity; as well as looking through maps and essays written by museum experts.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Wangaratta
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Roberto Salvatore, ACMI Content Development, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description: This program contains nine stories about residents from around the Wangaratta region in north-eastern Victoria. Covering the towns of Eldorado, King Valley, Greta, Whitfield and Whitlands, locals tell stories about their lives and their connection to the land and the community.

results.title: The Herd
results.creator_credit: Peter Lynch, Peter Starr and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1929, 62 year old Andy Bahr completed a 2,400 kilometre journey across the hostile and unmapped terrain of Alaska. What was remarkable about the journey that he completed with a team of Inuit and Sami herders, was that they herded 3,000 reindeer along the way. The Canadian government, in a well intentioned move to provide a livelihood for the Mackenzie Delta Inuit, had purchased the herd, which now required transportation. The drive was expected to take 18 months; it lasted 6 years. Filmed on location from the Bering Strait in Alaska to the Beaufort Sea in the Northwest Territories, this stunning odyssey combines historical documentation, epic myth and irreverent humour to follow Bahr’s quest to the edge of the world.

results.title: Leningrad
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Angus MacQueen, Tom Roberts, BBC and October Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Hand of Stalin”.
In the 1930s Stalin consolidated his power by creating a strict heirarchical level of command which depended upon paranoia and authoritarian repression for success. Millions of people were accused of “crimes against the state” and forced to sign confessions in show trials which only added to the growing societal hysteria. In interviews with both survivors and administrators of the “purges”, we see how the use of informers and the secret police led to a social order of mistrust where neigbour turned on neighbour and sibling on sibling. Filmed in the old city of Leningrad this powerful documentary shows how the purges, with their subsequant tortures, imprisonments and violence are still the cause of deep anguish for contemporary Russians.

results.title: Leningradskaya: a village in southern Russia
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Tom Roberts, BBC and October Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Hand of Stalin”.
In 1929, Stalin implemented a massive process of forced farm collectivisation which saw millions of peasants forcibly removed from their land. Ill-conceived and carelessly administered, the collectivisation process resulted in millions of peasants suffering deportation, imprisonment and finally death by starvation as the process led to a massive famine. Interviews with peasants, old Communist Party activists and survivors of the famine provide an eloquent and moving testament to the abuse of power enacted by Stalin in his iron-willed determination to make collectivisation a success.

results.title: The Hand of Stalin
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Tom Roberts, British Broadcasting Corporation and October Films
results.brief_description: A three part series examining the history of Stalinism in the former Soviet UnioN focusing on oral histories of people who lived through the turbulent and totalitarian Communist regime of the late 1930s. As they relive memories of collectivisation, the purges and the Gulags, the series becomes an almost unbearable testament to the brutality of power. However, by talking to peasants, intellectuals, former KGB and dissenters, the series avoids histrionics and controversy and allows the dignity of people’s voices to tell their own stories.

results.title: The Hat
results.creator_credit: Faith Hubley, John Hubley, Institute for International Peace and Storyboard
results.brief_description: An amusing treatment of the serious matter of World Peace and International Disputes. Two sentries are patrolling the border between hostile countries; one drops his hat and it falls across the line. When he tries to retrieve it war becomes imminent. Uses an interesting liquid form of animation. Dialogue and music are improvised by Dizzy Gillespie and Dudley Moore.
